data.title: The Marcus Corporation: Still Cheap After The Q4 Run-Up
data.description:
Marcus Corporation (MCS) reported earnings yesterday, and, as usual, Wall Street underestimated them (the third straight double beat).

What’s unusual this time isn’t that.

It’s that I actually went to the movies for the first time in seven years!

Well, if you follow my articles here on Seeking Alpha and read my write-up about another movie theater operator, Cineplex (CGX:CA), you should know that the last time I left home to see a movie was to watch Tarantino's latest film ('Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood').

I ended up watching 'The Housemaid' because my wife wanted to—I can already hear the jokes—and, other than overpriced popcorn, it was a good experience.

But it seems I wasn't the only one who ended up going to the movies this quarter.

As I told you, Marcus is in a sweet spot right now.

Both the Theatres and Hotels divisions have clear catalysts ahead (a pipeline full of family films for FY 2026 and the end of major renovations on key assets like the Hilton Milwaukee), monetization possibilities given the high concentration of owned properties, and a clean balance sheet.

This gives them optionality.

If heavy Capex is behind them, the Net LT Debt/EBITDA is very close to pre-pandemic levels at 1.4x, and there are leveraged competitors out there paying rent, they not only have the capacity to increase shareholder returns from dividends and buybacks but also continue to be a consolidator in the Midwest.

And that's exactly what I highlighted in my last article here.

Speaking of past articles, we're up ~10% since I started covering this company last September, well ahead of the S&P, which delivered just over 6% in the same stretch.

Of course, not all stocks of this type are booming.

Only two companies in the sector beat the S&P during the same period, and Marcus is one of them.

Cineplex, for example, has already fallen almost 10% in the same period.

To tell you the truth, that doesn't scare me. Cineplex has always been a story of divestment and deleveraging, something quite different from Marcus, as I showed you.

But despite the good results, I told you I was targeting a range of $20 to $23.50 in one or two years. So, we still have an upside of ~20 to 25% until then, which, added to the mid-digit shareholder yield I was projecting, gives us a fairly large margin of safety.

So, how's the thesis going?

Theatres: Normalization in Sight?

Although I, and a few other folks, have recently returned to the cinema, the narrative that many have tried to sell—that there will be a return to pre-pandemic numbers this year—is a lie.

If we add up the domestic box office for the entire year, we arrive at something slightly above $8.6 billion (only 1% above 2024 but almost 24% below 2019).

You could even argue that 2019 isn't such a comparable year, since many major releases came out, like Avengers: Endgame and The Lion King, but if you look back, in almost every pre-pandemic year the domestic box office exceeded $10 billion.

Besides not having normalized yet, the box office also hasn't reached the $9 billion projected by some analysts.

If you ask me, I think more was expected from some films with old superhero formulas like Captain America and Superman.

Animated films like 'A Minecraft Movie' and 'Lilo & Stitch' together grossed almost 10% of the total box office, which corroborates the thesis that family films have been much more profitable.

As I told you in my last two articles on Marcus, FY 2026 will be full of these family films like Zootopia 2 (which was released at the end of November and has already grossed $86.3 million, something like $928,000 per day), Toy Story 5, Super Mario Galaxy, and others.

All are sequels, of course. Even so, all should surpass $300 million in domestic box office (something that only six films managed to surpass last year).

Based on my estimates (considering Avengers: Doomsday will only be released in December), I think they could surpass that $9 billion estimate to something closer to $9.5 billion, with cheaper films (like The Housemaid and Wuthering Heights) boosting Gen Z and Millennial viewership.

But what about FY 2027?

Many say this year will be even better, with strong family titles like Frozen 3, Shrek 5 (that one I'll definitely want to see), and Minions 3.

Could this be the catalyst to push domestic box office numbers above $10 billion? I wouldn't venture to say, but there's a chance.

At Marcus, they achieved sales of $123.8 million in Q4 FY 2025, an increase of approximately 2.1% compared to the same period last year.

Beyond the one-off effect of the release of the film 'Song Sung Blue' (a very important film for the Milwaukee community in particular), Marcus has been able to see revenue growth through pricing.

If you look at the KPIs for the quarter, visitation fell 5.7% and was fully offset by a 12.7% increase in the average ticket price. Along with that, F&B per capita also jumped 7.2%.

Overall, they outperformed the national average by a good chunk of 760 bp.

Notice that this isn't the traditional expansion (the kind we saw even before the pandemic) of organic growth via volume, nor the previous low-price strategies of afternoon matinees. This is a premiumization strategy, and, given the elasticity of demand, it's working quite well.

If we consider that small jump in the year's box office and Marcus achieving some gains in pricing and cross-selling on family films, I imagine that instead of Theatres revenue growing at a low-single-digit rate as it did in FY 2025, it will increase to a mid-single-digit rate (something between 4 and 6%), taking them to $481.2 to $490.4 million.

The big question would be the margins.

With that premium push, they lifted the operating margin in the division from 4.9% to 6.3%. If that trend holds, mid-to-high-single-digit margins don't seem out of reach.

Answering the question I posed at the beginning of this section, if it happens, the normalization of box office revenue would occur in early 2027, with Marcus gaining market share while the industry continues to compete on price.

How Paramount Helped Theatre Operators

A piece of good news for theater operators that came out in the media today (February 27th, the day I'm writing this article) was the long-awaited Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) deal with Paramount (PSKY).

And, to be honest, I didn't follow the intricacies of it. That's not exactly my area of ​​expertise.

But since I cover Marcus and other operators in this industry, Paramount buying Warner Bros. instead of Netflix (NFLX) saved them a lot of headaches.

To better understand this, we have to go back to David Ellison's statements during the bidding war.

He explicitly said:

  1. There will be a guaranteed minimum window of 45 days before releases go to streaming (more or less what it was in the post-pandemic period, when they reduced it from ~80 to 90 days);
  2. For major box office hits (I imagine films grossing over $300 million domestically), the idea is that the window should be 60 to 90 days;
  3. Paramount produces approximately 30 films annually for theatrical release.

Looking at it bluntly, if they actually follow through on these promises, of course—this would extend Paramount's average window of ~30 days, which is more than a week shorter than the industry average.

This all seems like a win for the establishment and, consequently, for Marcus.

There's no doubt that Netflix would try its best to push very short windows, further shortening the theatrical lifespan of each film.

It's fair to wonder if Paramount can maintain that volume of releases every year, like what happened with Disney (DIS) and Fox post-merger, but I think that's the lesser of two evils.

Hotels: Smart Allocation and What to Expect in 2026

Hotels are also holding up well, especially assets that have just come out of renovations, like the Hilton Milwaukee.

If you've read my write-ups on casinos like Monarch (MCRI) and Boyd Gaming (BYD), you'll know that the operators outperforming the national average are those that are constantly renovating their assets. One of the few local assets that hadn't been renovated, The Orleans, hampered the entire segment.

Take the Strip as an example. Operators that aren't upscale are seeing a significant drop in ADR and, ultimately, RevPAR. But this is happening elsewhere too, like in the South (Houston is a good example) and even in the Midwest, where Marcus has most of its assets.

According to data they revealed in the earnings call, in the U.S. RevPAR increased by only 0.8% (ADR-driven, of course), and in the Midwest, Marcus's competing hotels fell by 2% in FY 2025 as a whole.

Looking at the numbers they pulled in the last quarter, you can see they outperformed the national average by a large chunk.

ADR increased 5.6% (driven by renovations and premiumization of certain assets), and occupancy fell only 1.2% to 60.2%.

Marcus aimed and hit the 'k-shaped economy' at a very opportune time.

RevPAR grew 3.5%, about 550 bp higher than competitors in the Midwest.

You can also see the full-year effects of the renovations.

With rooms closed part of the year, Hotels revenue grew only 2.6% in the full FY 2025, with the adjusted EBITDA margin remaining virtually flat year-over-year.

Okay, but if they premiumized their room offering, why did margins shrink?

That's simple. Some rooms remained closed during the renovation period, as well as certain areas like the convention center and part of the lobby. Since fixed costs remained stable, it's understandable that they would be less diluted while assets are under renovation.

For the entire FY 2026, management expects RevPAR growth in the low-single-digits, more or less stable with Q4 FY 2025 (likely with some pressure on occupancy and ADR increasing). But the difference here is that bookings for this year are ~3% higher than FY 2025.

If I had to make a definitive prediction here, I'd say revenue would continue to grow in the low-to-mid single digits ($304 to $312.9 million) and margins would be slightly fatter compared to last year.

Unlike other hotel chains, the World Cup won't be a huge boost here.

Only Kansas City was chosen to host games, and since Marcus hasn't had properties there since 2015 (it sold the Phillips Hotel to focus on other markets), we probably won't see a very strong increase in bookings.

Good Old Cash Generation

In summary, my midpoint revenue projections for FY 2026 are approximately $800 million, closely matching the consensus of $796.5 million that Wall Street is targeting.

Since they've been surprised every quarter recently, I'd say I'll stick with my projection.

Premiumization efforts should push the EBITDA margin to ~13% (it's been hovering at 12.8% for the last two years), which would give us a full-year EBITDA of $104 million.

Using the same 85% conversion rate I used in the last analysis, we could project an OCF of $88.4 million. That time we needed to project Capex, but now we know it should be between $50 and $55 million.

This slightly reduces our previous FCF projection of $40 to $45 million to $33.4 to $38.4 million.

Even so, if we project dividends of $0.32 per share annually (a return of $9.8 million counting on the 30.7 million shares outstanding), they would be covered at ~3.6x the midpoint of the FCF.

If they use another $10 million to repurchase shares at ~$20 per share (being a little more conservative here), they would repurchase and retire 500,000 shares (buyback yield of just over 1.6%).

We are still left with a low-to-mid-single-digit shareholder yield. But since I believe they will soon increase dividends back to what they were before the pandemic, I'm aiming for a mid-single-digit yield very soon.

Still Cheap?

Even though I think my previous price target of $20 to $23.50 is quite current, I believe we could take a look at the P/CF since these numbers are right in front of us.

Assuming the buybacks do reduce the outstanding shares to 30.2 million and the OCF comes in at $88.4 million (OCF per share of $2.92), Marcus's 5-year average multiple indicates that they usually trade at ~8.2x that.

If you look at the pre-pandemic period and imagine a scenario of normalization ahead, the price target is only slightly above my projections at ~$23.90 per share.

I will reiterate my 'Buy' rating on Marcus, eyeing this minimum 20% upside and a low-to-mid-single-digit shareholder yield.

Unless we head into a recession, the combination of a strong FY 2026–FY 2027 film slate and ongoing hotel premiumization makes this investment case look less risky from here. I also support the M&A thesis in the Midwest given the low leverage of the balance sheet.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: March 2026 Monthly
data.description:
March seems to be more about the unfolding of current forces driving the capital markets rather than new forces or policies. All the G10 central banks except the Reserve Bank of New Zealand meet in March, and none are likely to change policy.

China formalizes its next Five-Year Plan. In the US, the Supreme Court's ruling that the president's use of emergency powers to levy widespread tariffs is not legal was not unexpected, and the administration's "Plan B" is gradually being unveiled. The UK government faces an early electoral test. Japan has already shown how quickly crowded trades unwind when the political narrative shifts. The political cycle is no longer background noise. It is part of the macro regime.

China: Resilience as Strategy

The National People’s Congress will translate party guidance into the 2026–2030 Five-Year Plan. The themes are familiar: innovation, technological self-reliance, green development, and supply-chain security. What has changed is emphasis. Resilience now stands alongside growth. National security is embedded in economic planning.

Expect multi-year support for semiconductors, AI, advanced manufacturing, and green technologies. “Dual circulation” remains the framework: strengthen domestic demand and indigenous capability while maintaining external ties that serve national objectives.

For markets, three implications follow. First, industrial policy is structural. Subsidies, directed lending, and procurement policy are long-term commitments, not cyclical levers. Second, foreign firms in sensitive sectors face higher regulatory and political hurdles. Access is increasingly conditional.

Third, trade friction is hardwired into the system. Even absent new sanctions or tariffs, subsidy regimes and security controls keep tensions elevated. China is not retreating from global trade. It is reshaping it around strategic autonomy. “Business as usual” is fading as a baseline assumption.

United States: The Creaky Tariff Floor

“Liberation Day” implied peak effective tariffs near 28%, up from roughly 3% at the start of 2025. Since then, pauses, carve-outs, and substitutions have lowered the realized burden. Effective rates appeared to be around 12-14%. That is still the highest sustained level since the 1930s.

The Supreme Court ruled against the administration's use of emergency powers to levy most of the tariffs. While many expected the court's decision, reports suggested that some businesses sold their refund rights to hedge funds and non-bank financial institutions. The court sent the issue of refunds back to the lower courts. Shortly after the decision was announced, President Trump unveiled Plan B: a 10% across-the-board tariff under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974 to address balance-of-payments problems. Without Congressional support for the tariffs, the president's authority is limited to 150 days.

The following day, Saturday, February 21, President Trump raised the general levy to 15%. The legality may be challenged. On one level, the US does not have a balance of payment problem. Under floating exchange rates, the current account is offset by the capital account in the balance of payments. Rather than the adjustment being made by transferring gold, the adjustment is made by capital flows to offset the broad trade deficit.

We suspect the deterioration of the US net international investment position would pass legal muster, and it would take more than 150 days to exhaust a legal challenge. And it is not clear in the first place that the judiciary will challenge the executive claim of an emergency. The Supreme Court's ruling on the tariffs implemented under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act did not challenge the emergency status but the power to tariff under it. Most of the other tariff authority will require the administration to work with Congress, but the Republican majorities are narrow, and there is little room for dissent in the ranks.

Then there is monetary policy. With the investigation into the Federal Reserve continuing, the confirmation process for Kevin Warsh may be delayed, but if all goes according to plan, the meeting he chairs will be in June, and the Fed funds futures market has a strong chance of a cut then.

We suspect that a Warsh-led Federal Reserve will allow the administration to pursue two other transformative policies and will take some time to unfold. First, there is already speculation about a new Federal Reserve-US Treasury accord, which in some ways reverses the prevailing one from the early 1950s that recognized greater operational independence for the central bank.

Second, there may be an attempt to revalue gold, which is being carried at about $42.20 a troy ounce. In theory, it seems reasonable. However, setting such a volatile commodity at or near market prices does not seem prudent. And some decision-making rules to address revaluation or devaluation should also be part of the decision. The Treasury would present new gold certificates to the Federal Reserve, which would credit the Treasury's account accordingly.

United Kingdom: Political Premium Returns

The UK has two vulnerabilities: politics and economics.

Prime Minister Starmer faces May local elections that will be read as an early referendum on fiscal restraint and incremental reform. Real incomes remain pressured. Public services are strained. Patience is finite.

Within the Labour Party, Starmer's challengers are on the left. The Greens carried the Gorton and Denton special election at the end of February. Poor results in the May elections could strengthen the left wing of the Labour Party's hand. If trying to outflank the UK Reform Party did not work, maybe product differentiation could. However, the markets may object and could take it out on the Gilts and sterling.

The UK economy ended 2025 with little forward momentum. The economy expanded by 0.1% quarter-over-quarter in Q4 25. Unemployment reached 5.2% in the quarter, the highest since the pandemic. Regular private sector wage growth slowed to 3.4%, the slowest in over five years.

Japan: Crowded Trades Break Fast

Japan offered a reminder that positioning matters as much as policy.

Sanae Takaichi’s snap-election victory delivered the LDP its largest majority since World War II. The platform blended fiscal support with medium-term consolidation and a cautious approach to BOJ normalization. It was continuity with a stronger mandate.

Going into the vote, the consensus was clear: looser fiscal policy, gradual BOJ tightening, weaker yen, and higher JGB yields. The trade was crowded.

When uncertainty evaporated and post-election messaging leaned toward sustainability, markets reversed sharply. The yen rallied. Long-dated JGB yields fell as shorts were squeezed. The one-way weak yen narrative cracked.

The lesson is broader than Japan. When a trade becomes a proxy for a global regime assumption - in this case, that Japan would tolerate persistent depreciation - it becomes vulnerable to even modest political shifts.

Politics is not interfering with fundamentals. It is a fundamental.

Bannockburn's World Currency Index

Bannockburn's World Currency Index, a GDP-weighted basket of the currencies of the dozen largest economies, rose for the fourth consecutive month. It eked out a minor gain of about 0.15% after the nearly 1% gain in January. It looks poised to move higher, consistent with additional dollar losses.

All of the G10 components but the Australian dollar fell against the greenback in February. Encouraged by a hawkish Reserve Bank of Australia, the Australian dollar gained a little more than 2.1% in February. Sterling was the weakest. It tumbled about 1.5%. The yen lost a little more than half as much.

Emerging market currencies in Bannockburn's World Currency Index rose in February, with the noted exception of the Russian ruble, which fell almost 1.6%. The Brazilian real's nearly 2.7% gain was the strongest component in the BWCI last month, followed by the Chinese yuan, rose for the eighth consecutive month, and its nearly 1.4% gain put it slightly ahead of the Mexican peso's 1.35% appreciation. The Indian rupee's 1.1% gain was its largest since last April. The South Korean won was slightly better than flat.

Bannockburn's World Currency Index reached its best level since September 2024, around 92.25 in mid-February, before consolidating. The consolidation looks broadly constructive, and we expect it to continue to trend higher. At the end of last year, we projected potential toward 94.75-96.00 this year, a roughly 5-7% gain, reflecting our bearish US dollar view. That still seems broadly fair.

U.S. Dollar: The Dollar Index fell to four-year lows in late January, near 95.50. It recovered in February and stalled around 98.00. This met the technical retracement objectives, and the risk is a return to the February low, about 96.50. A break re-targets the January low. Sentiment towards the dollar remains fragile, and the preferences revealed by the administration's policies are consistent with a weaker dollar. Still contrary to the "sell America" mantra in the media, the Treasury's International Capital report states that foreign investors were net buyers of $1.35 trillion of US stocks and bonds in 2025, the most since 2022. Yet, studies suggest that the dollar exposure was hedged. Comments from numerous Fed officials have encouraged the market to push back the first cut until July. At the end of January, the Fed funds futures strip implied an almost 87% chance of a cut in June, which could be the first meeting Warsh chairs if the confirmation process were timely. It is being threatened by the ongoing investigation into the Fed's renovations of its headquarters. By the end of February, the odds slipped to about 63%. The futures market has about 60 bp of easing discounted for this year, up from 53 bp at the end of January. The March 17-18 FOMC meeting will see updated projections. In December, the median dot, which hid a wide dispersion of view, anticipated one cut this year.

Euro: After it appreciated more than 4.5 cents in the second half of January, the euro pulled back and consolidated for most of February. A base appears to have been forged in the $1.1745-65 area. It looks poised to move higher in March after violating the month-long downtrend line. Initial potential may extend back to the $1.1900-50 area in the coming weeks. Eurozone growth looks stable, even if not inspiring. Infrastructure and defense spending will contribute. The ECB meets on March 19. There is practically no doubt that policy is on hold. The new economic projections are likely to be little changed with the central bank anticipating inflation will hold below the 2% target this year and next. Speculation surfaced that the ECB President Lagarde may step down before her term ends (October 27). She seems to have denied this but, in any case, it is not imminent. Two German states hold elections in March. Baden-Wurttemberg's contest will be held on March 6. The Greens won in 2021 and formed a coalition with the CDU. The CDU is running a little ahead in the polls, and CDU-Green coalition looks to be the most likely outcome. Rhineland-Palatinate holds its election on March 22. The polls suggest a CDU-SPD coalition may replace the current SPD-Greens-FDP tie-up. Denmark has called for a snap election on March 24, ostensibly to secure a stronger mandate to resist US pressure on Greenland.

(As of February 27, indicative closing prices, previous in parentheses)

Spot: $1.1812 ($1.1850) Median Bloomberg One-month forecast: $1.1900 ($1.1827) One-month forward: $1.1832 ($1.1867) One-month implied vol: 5.9% (7.3%)

Japanese Yen: The yen looks vulnerable. The two new nominations to the central bank board confirm the market's understanding that Prime Minister Takaichi wants an accommodative monetary policy in the face of the fiscal stimulus. At the same time, the BOJ's reluctance to tighten more aggressively pre-dates the ascendance of Takaichi. Core CPI peaked last May at 3.7%. In January, the latest print was at 2.0%, matching the slowest pace since March 2022. The economy practically ground to a halt last year. Q4 25 growth year-over-year was a meager 0.1%. Growth appears to be off to a stronger start this year. Still, the swaps markets see practically no chance of a hike at the March 19 BOJ meeting. A hike at the start of the new fiscal year in April seems reasonable. However, the risk of intervention has slackened, and the market appears eager to test official resolve. A return to the JPY158-JPY159 area in the coming weeks looks reasonable.

Spot: JPY156.05 (JPY154.80) Median Bloomberg One-month forecast: JPY154.00 (JPY154.40) One-month forward: JPY155.65 (JPY154.40). One-month implied vol: 9.2% (9.9%)

British Pound: Sterling was the weakest of the G10 currencies in February. It fell by about 1.7% against the dollar and 1.3% against the euro. The generally poor string of economic data, outside of retail sales, saw the pendulum of market sentiment swing toward a cut as soon as the March 19 Bank of England meeting. In the swaps market, the odds of a cut rose to nearly 80% from less than 20% at the end of January. The market has another cut fully discounted in H2, which would bring the base rate to 3.25%. The selling pressure on sterling does not appear exhausted. We suspect there is potential toward $1.3250-$1.3300 in the coming weeks. A rare piece of favorable news for the Gilt market may come after Chancellor Reeves' spring statement in early March. The Debt Management Office may announce a GBP59 bln (20%) decline in gross Gilt sales during the new fiscal year. Near GBP245 bln, it would be the least gross sales in three years.

Spot: $1.3482 ($1.3865) Median Bloomberg One-month forecast: $1.3600 ($1.3600) One-month forward: $1.3480 ($1.3585) One-month implied vol: 7.2% (7.3%)

Canadian Dollar: For the first time in four months, the Canadian dollar fell against the US dollar in February. The losses were minor (~0.35%). Its prospects look better in March. The US dollar stalled in the CAD1.3700-CAD1.3725 area last month. We suspect there is potential back toward the lower end of the recent range (CAD1.3480-CAD1.3500). While the economy has yet to find an even keel, the 0.6% annualized contraction in Q4 25 overstates the weakness. Inventories were drawn down aggressively and slashed 4.2 percentage points off the headline pace. The trade balance improved and the domestic private sector expanded. Despite weakness in house prices, household spending rose 1.7% (after falling 0.8% in Q3) at an annual pace. With price pressures still firm, the Bank of Canada is still very much on the sidelines. The USMCA continues to offer protection for Canada, but the USMCA review starting around midyear poses risks. At the same time, Canada is gradually diversifying its export markets away from the US.

Spot: CAD1.3650 (CAD 1.3620) Median Bloomberg One-month forecast: CAD1.3700 (CAD1.3800) One-month forward: CAD1.3630 (CAD1.3585) One-month implied vol: 4.9% (6.1%)

Australian Dollar: Profit-taking after the Reserve Bank of Australia hiked its cash rate target on February 3 saw the Australian dollar test our downside objective of $0.6900. It did not stay there long. Within a little more than a week, it reached nearly $0.7150, a three-year high. The firm inflation readings and strength in the labor market suggest hawkish guidance at the March 17 central bank meeting, paving the ground for a hike at the following meeting in early May. Monetary policy divergence and Australia's commodity exposure, including critical materials, underpin the Australian dollar's attractiveness. The Australian dollar's nearly 2.1% gain in February led the G10 currency complex and brought the year-to-date gain to 6.5%. We initially thought potential toward $0.7200 this year seemed reasonable. Though more bullish than the consensus forecast, it is likely to prove too conservative. It may overshoot it in the coming weeks, but we are hesitant to recommend chasing as much good news appears already discounted. A 1-2 cent pullback may provide a better opportunity for those that can afford to be patient.

Spot: $0.7118 ($0.6695) Median Bloomberg One-month forecast: $0.7000 ($0.6700) One-month forward: $0.7120 ($0.6970) One-month implied vol: 9.3% (10.5%).

Mexican Peso: Last month, the dollar fell to a new low against the peso since June 2024, near MXN17.0865, but only after first slightly overshooting our upside corrective target (MXN17.50-55). The main forces that have lifted the peso by more than 4.5% in January-February remain intact. The yield pickup and relatively modest volatility, with 24-hour activity, it is attractive for dollar-based investors. Still, we recognize a regional theme, as five of the top eight performing emerging market currencies this year are from Latam. High rate and commodity exposure are a shared feature. While the dramatic shift in US policy was disruptive for Mexico, its exports to the US rose in 2025 and it remained the largest US trading partner for the third consecutive year. We suspect the market may be reluctant to take the dollar below the psychologically important MXN17.00 level while US President Trump continues to threaten to leave the USMCA. Mexico's central bank meets on March 26, and the extended pause is set to continue until at least closer to midyear. On the other hand, Brazil's central bank has signaled it will deliver its first rate cut at the March 18 meeting. The Selic rate is currently at 15%. Colombia's central bank meets at the end of March and is expected to hike 25 bp (to 10.50%).

Spot: MXN17.2270 (MXN17.4605) Median Bloomberg One-month forecast: MXN17.60 (MXN17.8685) One-month forward: MXN17.2765 (MXN17.5040) One-month implied vol: 9.2% (9.5%)

Chinese Yuan: Since the end of 2024, Beijing has allowed the yuan to gradually strengthen against the US dollar. Last year, the yuan appreciated in nine of the 12 months. It appreciated further in January and February this year to extend the streak to nine consecutive months of gains. It appreciated by almost 2% against the US dollar. It has appreciated by another 1.2% this year. The pace is too slow for Chinese critics, but the direction is clear. A stronger exchange rate achieves at least three policy objectives. First, on the margins, it may deflect some criticism over its huge trade surplus. Second, an appreciating currency is conducive to a foreign direct investment expansion strategy that is increasingly adopted by Chinese companies. Third, allowing the yuan to appreciate may also foster its greater use as an international currency. That said, the exchange rate target by Chinese officials is not known, and market participants need to stay vigilant, watching for cues. The PBOC announced two measures at the end of February that may steady the yuan in the short term, though we suspect it will continue to allow a gradual appreciation of the yuan. The central bank cut the required reserves for foreign exchange forwards, which makes them more attractive. It also boosted Chinese banks’ ability to provide yuan liquidity offshore.

Spot: CNY6.8620 (CNY6.9570) Median Bloomberg One-month forecast: CNY6.9250 (CNY6.9535) One-month forward: CNY6.8830 (CNY6.9625) One-month implied vol: 3.4% (4.7%)

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Workday: A Generational Contrarian Buy
data.description:
Editor's note: Seeking Alpha is proud to welcome Wilson Ye as a new contributing analyst. You can become one too! Share your best investment idea by submitting your article for review to our editors. Get published, earn money, and unlock exclusive SA Premium access. Click here to find out more »

I have 7 years of "boots-on-the-ground" experience implementing Workday. I have taken panic calls during Christmas holidays due to an integration failure caused by accident. I sat in meetings where executives grilled me with "What if it doesn't work" questions. I have seen projects delayed as customers could not complete the testing process in time. I understand the gravity of building and maintaining a reliable enterprise system—a reality many market participants currently take for granted.

Recently, Workday and other software leaders have been severely punished as the "Software is being disrupted by AI" rhetoric took hold. In this hyper-emotional environment, the market seizes upon any flaw to punish the stock. However, I believe this sell-off is unwarranted. The market is underestimating the complexity, sophistication, and "trust moat" of the Workday ecosystem. I am assigning a "buy" rating to Workday, as the market is currently pricing in a structural decline that my professional experience strongly contradicts.

Misunderstanding of the Enterprise SaaS Industry

If you ask any professional who works in the industry, you will certainly receive an answer that Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) is an incredibly difficult business. It is not a college midterm where an 85% is an "A"; it is a statement of legal and financial liability that demands 100% accuracy and strict regulatory compliance. Workday is the System of Record—the ultimate "truth" of an organization.

Critics claim AI agents may soon code curated software systems to disrupt or replace traditional SaaS players, including Workday. This might work for a seven-employee car shop, but not for the mid-to-large enterprises Workday targets. These organizations are deeply risk-averse. A failed enterprise system is catastrophic; no executive will hand the responsibility of payroll and financial integrity to a "smart but erratic" AI agent. Using Workday provides a "Peace of Mind" insurance that an unverified AI cannot offer. As a result, I do not believe large clients would develop their own native agents to handle massive amounts of data, meeting tremendous reporting and regulatory requirements while accepting the risk of a system failure. This is equivalent to handing the fate of their careers to a casino.

Think about it: even before AI, why didn’t clients build their own internal software? Because they don't just pay Workday for code; they pay for integrity, reputation, and indemnity. Even if I, as an experienced Workday professional, could build a technically functional ERP in weeks, I would never replace Workday because I lack decades of built-up trust and reliability. This "soft power" is a moat that AI agents cannot easily cross. That is why many reputable AI companies, including the developers of Claude, also use Workday to process their sensitive data, despite having the ability to build their own enterprise software.

The Market is Pricing in for the Worst

Workday's Strength in AI

During the most recent earnings call, I noticed several key highlights:

  • In FY26, Workday executed more than 1.7 billion AI actions.
  • In Q4, Workday "generated over $100 million in new ACV from emerging AI products", double from Q4 of last year.
  • Over 400 customers have adopted Workday's role-based agents.

I still remember the first time I implemented Workday AI features as a junior resource on a project several years ago. I led a mini project to use AI to scan red flags on expense reports. Now, Workday's AI capabilities have grown exponentially, and clients are excited about new features. My observations in the field support the claims from the management - that Workday's AI offerings are gaining momentum. As an incumbent sitting on an ocean of proprietary data, Workday is uniquely positioned to thrive.

I am particularly excited about Workday Sana. According to the comment from its management:

Sana Core brings conversational AI directly into Workday, so employees can get answers and complete tasks using Workday agents. Sana Enterprise extends the same experience beyond Workday by connecting enterprise tools, like Outlook and Google Drive and so many more, so employees can find information, create agents and automate workflows all in one place. That will create an entirely new way for our 75 million users to engage with Workday.

If I were a Workday customer, I would welcome a curated ERP system that promotes automation, streamlines business processes, and keeps the core infrastructure largely intact from large changes. In the world of ERP, "lift and shift" should be strictly avoided unless it is absolutely necessary. If I can conveniently enjoy all the reliable outcomes of AI while relying on a trusted infrastructure as my source of truth, why would I seek drastic replacements?

As stated above, I firmly believe that incumbents with excellent vision and execution skills will survive and thrive in the era of AI; those without a clear vision will become obsolete. Not all SaaS companies will survive, but I believe that Workday is well positioned to take on this challenge.

Market Irrationality

Having gone through ups and downs in the past, I believe that the market is so irrational that it assumes negative narratives about any incumbent software company. The presumption of guilt is what is behind the large catastrophe of software stocks, including Workday.

At ~$130 per share today, Workday is trading at:

  • 13x Forward Non-GAAP P/E: A historical low for the company.
  • 0.5 non-GAAP PEG: It is rare to see a growing technology company with 95%+ retention rates trading at 0.5 PEG. Historically, such a low valuation does not persist unless fundamentals worsen significantly.
  • ~10x Forward EV/FCF: This valuation currently sits at a decade low.
  • ~97% retention rate, showing no signs of customer abandonment.
Company/Benchmark Forward Revenue Growth Non-GAAP Op. Margin FCF Margin (%) Forward P/E Forward P/S Forward EV/FCF
Workday (WDAY) 13% 30% 29% 15 4 13
Oracle (ORCL) 14% 42% Abnormal 21 6 Abnormal
Salesforce (CRM) 10% 36% 35% 15 4 16
ServiceNow (NOW) 22% 29% 26% 92 10 34
Software Sector 11% 30% 27% 28 5 32
S&P 500 Avg ~8% ~19% ~15% ~22% 3 16

Peer valuation shows that Workday is trading at a significant discount to the sector average. Considering that Workday continues to demonstrate strong cash flow growth, moderated but still robust revenue growth, and a strong FCF margin, it warrants a premium to the S&P 500. If Workday is able to solidify its status as the AI-era ERP leader over the next several quarters, Workday should command a higher valuation premium.

Today, considering that most valuation multiples have contracted to historical lows, Workday is trading like a commodity stock with no growth prospects. There has been no material damage to any future earnings and cash flows of Workday, so its price action is largely attributable to the market sentiment. The market is correct to price in the risk of AI disruption, which warrants a contraction from historical norms, as new risks elevate the cost of debt and equity, resulting in a larger discount applied to its terminal value. However, the indiscriminate punishment across the sector has gone too far.

SBC Concerns

While many argue that its massive stock-based-compensation (SBC) presents a problem (GAAP P/E stands at 40x), I believe that we should compare apples to apples. SBC is not a new problem. It has been a well-known fact since Workday's inception and has been factored into Workday's valuation throughout its history. It's not as if the market suddenly began to care about SBC this morning.

Furthermore, the company has a buyback program that aggressively offsets its SBC. Last year, Workday repurchased 12.8 million shares, resulting in a net reduction of 1.5 million shares outstanding in the past year. Workday currently guides to 3.18 billion in free cash flow for FY27 - a 15% increase. I believe Workday will meet its guidance and provide new resources for further share buybacks. Should the stock remain suppressed, the company will be able to repurchase shares at a significant discount.

The pessimistic sentiment presents a generational contrarian buy opportunity. Just under a year ago, MU was trading at $65 and NVDA was at $90 when the AI sentiment was low. The current skepticism around SaaS is repeating the same story, though it may take several months for the market to process the reality. Of course, there will be winners and losers, but my bullish stance comes from my professional experience in the ecosystem. I believe that many market participants have never navigated an enterprise system implementation and, as a result, deeply underestimate the stickiness and sophistication of Workday.

Risks

Of course, Workday carries significant risks. The competitive landscape in the AI era has effectively produced a new S-curve, and Workday must prove it can execute its AI strategy to meet customer demands.

Headcount Pressure

The market assumes that a significant percentage of the workforce will be reduced due to AI automation. Since Workday's revenue still relies primarily on a per-seat basis, labor market uncertainty may cause per-seat revenue to stagnate. Recently, Block (XYZ) just announced a 40% reduction in headcount, citing AI tools as a catalyst; this triggered a new wave of panic in all software stocks.

I am personally skeptical of this announcement, as many companies use "AI washing" to justify staff reductions, blaming layoffs on AI when they actually result from other business factors. However, in the long term, AI will eventually replace many jobs - especially entry-level roles. It is a part of an evolution that no one can avoid.

While I believe the concern is valid, Workday is actively adopting a new pricing model that charges clients based on usage instead of headcount. While total headcount may stagnate, the volume of transactions will not. Transactions will continue at scale generated by AI agents rather than human employees. AI will still require a source of truth and a reliable infrastructure to operate; Workday provides that "playground" for human-AI collaboration. While revenue growth may slow during this transition, I expect usage-based-revenue to normalize growth in the long run.

This is not the first time Workday has leveraged new products to revitalize its narrative. Workday Finance, Prism Analytics, Accounting Center, and Adaptive were all introduced to drive revenue as the traditional HCM and payroll markets matured. The ability to integrate new revenue streams in a dynamic environment is a critical skill that maximizes Workday's chance of success.

AI Execution Risk

Ironically, while the market views Workday as vulnerable to AI disruption, the key risk could be the opposite - what if AI is overrated?

If so, Workday may have invested billions into a product trend that offers more risk than reward. While many software companies embrace AI as a "politically correct" necessity, there is a risk that Workday is trying to change a business model that shouldn't be overly generous to AI to begin with.

For instance, while I appreciate the boldness of Workday Sana, its potential damage is significant. In my experience, customers struggle more with "what to do" than "how to do it". As AI interacts with infrastructure to automate processes, a "wrong order" could result in "automated chaos" - incorrect tasks performed on a massive scale. Negative user experiences could cause risk-averse clients to retreat, damaging Workday's revenue.

As I previously mentioned, ERP is a conservative business. This protects Workday’s core infrastructure but may also diminish the return on AI investments. AI add-ons take time to build momentum, but a few bad incidents are enough to spook large customers. Therefore, the quality of execution is key. If Workday fails to deliver high-quality AI, two outcomes are possible:

  1. Systematic Poor Returns: The ERP ecosystem may not be an ideal place for large-scale AI. If the market realizes this, Workday and its competitors will face margin compression and a poor return on AI spend.
  2. Competitive Displacement: If AI is a gift to ERP, but Workday’s offerings are less competitive than peers', the company will lose market share and face margin pressure.

As AI-embedded ERP products are in their infancy, it is difficult to predict which risk will prevail. Therefore, diversification is recommended. Investors seeking exposure to the ERP industry should diversify across several large players to minimize specific execution risks.

Conclusion

At today's price, I believe that the market has priced in maximum pessimism. While short-term volatility is expected, long-term value will prevail as the narrative shifts over the next several quarters. Instead of panicking over the slight guidance miss, we should emphasize Workday's unique position and moat in the enterprise infrastructure space. I believe now is the time to accumulate quality software stocks, including Workday. If everyone was chasing it at $280, why wouldn't you want it at $130?

data.title: Why There Are Better Alternatives Than Welltower In 2026
data.description:
I used to be fairly heavily invested in US REITs. The reason I am not right now is because REITs are bad investments or bad choices; it's because a significant shift in USD/SEK FX made me leave most of those investments (that were at a profit) behind. Now that FX has normalized, I'm looking at what REITs to go into, and I've been investing in a couple of them again. Today, I look at Welltower (WELL), and I'll show you why, in this case, I have not invested in this particular one.

When I pick investments or even companies to cover, I focus on a couple of things. Fundamentals, profitability, and valuation are core among the qualities that I weigh heavily. I try not to rely too heavily on a company having to "outperform" the market or its own expectations. When a company's performance is, in fact, dependent on a specific, expected outperformance, I tend to be very dubious about investing in it. It's because even if we have solid accuracy ratios and forecasts (historically speaking), there's always a certain risk in investing in companies like this. To me, that risk is higher than investing in a company that is fundamentally undervalued for what it is at its heart, irrespective of future outperformance.

To put it another way, I'd rather invest in a cheap-quality company that grows very slowly, or even sometimes not at all, than I would in a company that trades at expensive multiples, and that's because investment return success (mine, in turn) is predicated on outperforming significantly, or even at all.

I believe the more "tilted" you are towards this tendency, the more of a value-oriented investor you can be argued to be. In this article, I'll be updating on Welltower following the company's recent bout of share price appreciation, following in turn the short decline we saw in November-December of 2025.

Welltower - The Upside Here is Tricky

Welltower is an A-rated healthcare REIT with an AFFO multiple of over 44x. During bad times, such as the GFC or even COVID-19, this company dropped to less than 13x.

I feel that this is a very good way to start out this article and updated coverage - to clarify that Welltower is currently at a multiple that it has never been at before (20+ years), and that is close to 3-4x the company's low end and more than 2x the typical average. Its closest peers in the industry trade at less than half the current P/AFFO and have better dividend yields, if not necessarily the same stellar credit rating as Welltower has.

First off, let's clarify why the company has risen to these multiple levels.

This has to do with the company's shift to a premium-to-pay model, coupled with a large portion of elderly individuals (the so-called "Silver Tsunami") driving demand for senior housing. But not just any senior housing - Welltower is focusing on that luxury senior housing.

Since the pandemic and the decline of many of these healthcare REITs (you can go back to some articles and companies from back then to see what happened to companies like Omega (OHI)), there's been a very sharp decline in construction of new capacity in senior housing - correlated with the current state of US housing, by the way.

But of course, these demographic tailwinds and advantages alone could never explain why a SHOP REIT like Welltower (previously) is trading at these significant multiples. There's more to it than that. Wall Street, despite the company's rather "nutty" valuation multiple relative to historical levels, after all, still has the company at a "BUY". So what gives?

Well, a definite core part of it is also that the company shifted its business model. Typical SHOP/Healthcare/Senior operators are passive landowners. They lease out the land/assets to others who do the operating for them and pay a lease. However, for some time now, the company has moved to an active model of owner-operation. The company's Senior Housing Operating (or SHOP) is part of this, delivering consistent, superior relative returns to the market. The company enhances this with its own data analytics to identify performers and underperformers, allowing them to strategically target and rectify margin issues before they even become a problem.

Its superior credit quality and debt metrics have allowed the company, relative to the BBB- (that's minus) rated companies in the sector, to buy up cheap properties in a market where supply is scarce.

Furthermore, as of current demographic trends, these growth metrics or trends are not expected to slow down but to pick up further. The strategic shift to this "luxury housing" is certainly the core of what is driving Welltower.

The recent trends, reported about 2 weeks ago, confirm the continued growth with the 13th consecutive quarter of 20% NOI growth. Welltower, due to the assets it owns, has some significant pricing power at this time - and in recent results, operating margins have exceeded 30%.

The company is not only buying things, but it's also selling them. Its recent plan includes the disposition of its outpatient medical portfolio at $6.4B, which will obviously free up a considerable amount of capital for potential reinvestment into new properties and assets. Money is being used, as of late, to buy up all UK-located senior properties.

Let's hold there for a moment. The company is selling all of its outpatient medical, or OM, portfolio for capital recycling. The rationale for this move is obviously to buy other things for that money.

I think this is a poor move. Why?

Because Welltower is selling "crown jewels" at what could be too-cheap (forward) prices in order to get deeper into SHOP. Welltower has spent many years becoming a solid OM operator. The sold portfolio had a more than 93% occupancy with very, very solid cash flows and much life left in it. I further like outpatient medical sectors because they act as a hedge against a downturn. Their sale represents Welltower giving up valuable diversification and income. It represents, as I see things, Welltower moving from a defensive income play into a very forward-looking, risk-taking growth player. Do we want that?

Well, that would depend on the price, wouldn't it? I certainly wouldn't want to put my money in an overvalued player who wanted to overpay for SHOP assets with the explanation of "demographics" while, in my view, ignoring some of the downside risk and the qualities of the very assets that it's selling.

Note that I said "overvalued" in the paragraph above. Let's presume for a moment that Welltower traded at, let's say, half of its current valuation. Then it would be a different ballgame - I would probably be interested, or at least willing to consider investing.

But right now, no matter how solid and how good the results, margins, cash flows, and other metrics are, it doesn't matter to me due to how much I have to pay to "get" those margins or returns. It's always about "what you pay for what you get". When there's a surge like this in a company, it's always extremely hard to see even the risk or potential for a turnaround of the company dropping once again. It has to do with complex trends - such as the risks of initial issues and risks being hidden by the "waves" of success that the company is going through - this has to do with cognitive bias on our part as investors. Confirmation bias is a "big thing" here. Too often I've heard investors or clients say, "Well, the company is still doing well". It might be, but that doesn't mean in a year.

The higher a company flies, the less it will take to start to make it tremble, metaphorically speaking.

You want an example of this? Look at many people's darling, NVIDIA (NVDA). Despite what even Nvidia bears like me would describe as a record-breaking quarter in every single metric, the company fell 5% on the trading day. This is proof to me that not only are many of these companies flying so high we can start talking about "Icarus flying too close to the sun", but we should also be talking about exits and risks for many more companies than just Nvidia.

This is one of them.

Welltower had a superb previous result period, but to me, valuation is what matters. The valuation for the company is as follows.

Valuation for Welltower - Not Justifiable Going Into 2026E

Let's start with the bull case. The company would, according to bull expectations, sustain its current expansion trajectory, margin growth, and earnings growth. They would have to "compound" the successes of 2025 into 2026 and work from there. I would argue that to make the bullish thesis work, the company must maintain double-digit NOI growth, and revenue must keep outperforming expenses. The company must also, in an attractive manner, execute on its pipeline and capital strategy. Growing at 44-45x P/AFFO would continue to drive a somewhat market-beating rate of return here.

It's not that I believe that the company will fail with all of these things; it's that I think that the risks aren't being properly considered.

What risks?

Think of it like a "weight" on the company. We've already seen the first significant tremble of the company under pressure - that was during November/December when the stock fell, only to now recover at earnings. Based on this, I say that if the company can keep the recent results trends up, I think it might outperform (even at just 15.11%, about 0.11% above my requirement).

For risks, we have a few.

As mentioned above, the company is leaving OM behind. Why? There's, to my mind, no good reason for this move (aside from capital recycling - but the company could have tapped equity or debt, easily, to handle this capital need.) The OM segment is growing. There's a structural shift from hospital to outpatient, driven by exactly the same demographic trends the company is citing. The need for OM will be higher, not lower. Yet WELL is, in my view, leaving "safe money" on the table here.

The company's new operating profile lacks diversification. Senior housing operations are further correlated to significant volatility due to the reliance on labor, occupancy dips, and other factors, unlike OM, which is much easier to continually fill and work with.

Further, by leaving the sector entirely, WELL is disregarding a multi-decade expertise that they've built up in OM. Over 150 people are leaving the company, people that the company trained and worked with. That's losing skill/expertise, and that's not positive.

I argue that Welltower should view the healthcare sector for seniors like an ecosystem. In doing what the company is doing, Welltower is giving up a core part of that ecosystem willingly and without really needing to do so.

Then there are fiscal considerations. The company is getting money for its OM portfolio and cycling it into what are now expensive assets. I believe there's a real risk that Welltower is selling solid-performance assets at what will be discounts to future cash flows while overpaying for assets that will be more volatile than the company expects them to be.

Based on this, I view the company as being unfavorably valued here.

My outlook is bearish. I give the company a premium to long-term AFFO at 25x, but that's as high as I can go for the FV. That comes to $180/share, with a PT of $155/share or lower. This target includes the assumption of future growth, just not as much growth as the market seems to be expecting. My share price targets include a significant correction from these overvalued tendencies over the coming 2-3. I believe we'll see a risk from rising costs relative to revenue growth, as well as the slow introduction of interest rate pressure. I believe that senior housing supply will, in fact, grow now that the supply situation is clear.

Once this supply and similar trends become clearer, this premium will, I believe, deflate. I believe this will result in missed growth metrics going forward and a lower AFFO on a per-share basis than expected. This also represents a failure for the company to deliver on its capital acquisitions because they're made at "too high" prices. If you want to adjust my targets, the variables are there for you to remove or edit. The shift in any of them towards the positive side would result in a higher FV/PT, ultimately towards the end the $240-$350/share target that some analysts have.

I am not one of them, however.

My thesis for Welltower for 2026 is as follows.

Thesis

Welltower is a very solid REIT, with what some might argue are best-in-class fundamentals with significant upside. However, the company's strategy does not convince me that the upside for 2026-2028E will be as high as it is expected, and I believe the company's plan to succeed is flawed in terms of risk/reward at this particular valuation.

I view the move from the solid OM segment as the wrong move as a justification for the capital recycling strategy. What I would have liked to see is a hybrid approach or an entirely equity/debt approach to fund this move - perhaps with more care and consideration as well.

I believe the risks are now higher than before and, coupled with the valuation, are unsustainably high. For that reason, I update with an FV of $180/share and a PT of $155/share.

Here are my criteria and how the company fulfills them (in italics).

  • This company is overall qualitative.
  • This company is fundamentally safe/conservative & well-run.
  • This company pays a well-covered dividend.
  • This company is currently cheap.
  • This company has a realistic upside that is high enough, based on earnings growth or multiple expansion/reversion.

The company fulfills 3 out of 3 quality indicators and 0 out of 2 valuation indicators. That means 3/5 "stars" here, which typically isn't enough. Based on this and a valuation target of $155/share, I see a risk/reward-adjusted upside that's attractive enough for me. I give the company a "Hold" rating as of February 2026.
